title: The Power of Diversity (Tighty Whities Experiment) 1/3

tasks.task: Conducting a long-term agricultural field experiment involving bean and corn rotations with different crop diversification.
subtasks: Preparing experimental plots with varying rotations (e.g., two-year corn and soybean, four-year corn-pea-winter-wheat-soy).
Implementing a no-till farming method across all experimental plots.
Monitoring and comparing nitrous oxide emissions from different rotation systems.
Tracking changes in soil organic matter across the different rotation systems over time.
Evaluating yield differences between four-year and two-year rotation systems, particularly for soybeans.

tasks.task: Presenting an educational demonstration comparing two-year and four-year crop rotations.
subtasks: Setting up a visual experiment to demonstrate soil decomposition rates.
Sharing data on the benefits of crop rotational diversity (e.g., reduced nitrous oxide emission, enhanced soil organic matter, improved yields).

tasks.task: Discussing the impact of diverse crop rotations on soil health and sustainability.
subtasks: Explaining the relationship between crop diversity, root exudates, soil structure, and nutrient retention.
Describing the role of organic residue diversity in soil health.

tasks.task: Observing the rate of decomposition in agricultural soils under different management practices.
subtasks: Collecting samples from different experimental plots for decomposition rate analysis.
Measuring and comparing the decomposition rates of residues from various rotations.
